segment.tokens: The Malayan Sun bear ( Ursus Malayensis ) has a long tongue short smooth fur very extensible flexible lips large claws
Sir Stamford Raffles had one
one was brought up in the nursery with his children
when he joined the party at table
Sir Stamford Raffles would only eat the choicest fruit
drink champagne
even be of humour
when there was none of the latter
He was very
He never required chastised
This bear a cat a dog a lory from New Holland used to eat amicably of the same dish
His favorite playfellow however was the
although he was teased
he worried
by it incessantly
He grew
He pulled plants trees up by the roots , the latter of which were too large for him to embrace
by the roots , the latter of which were too large for him to embrace
The Bornean bear ( Ursus Euryspilus ) is of the most amusing and playful of all bears
begs in the most earnest manner
when it has more to eat
than it can hold in its paws and mouth as if to keep it
places the surplus on its hinder feet
being soiled
vexed irritated
it when irritated will never be reconciled as long
as the offender is in its sight
It does much injury to cocoa-nut trees biting off the top shoots tearing down the fruit
Badgers belong to the same division of Carnivora as Bears
Badgers differ from them not only in size in dentition
while they claim a sort of miniature relationship
This forms them into a separate genus
They afford many a day
what is called sport to those who choose to hunt them
those choose to hunt them
many a day they evince much sagacity in their efforts to escape
I am to say the custom tying them into an empty cask baiting them with dogs no longer
exists
They are by nature slothful and heavy
They are easily tamed
when roused
are
They have a gland under the tail , which secretes a liquid of most disagreeable odour , and causes them to pass into a sort of proverb
the tail secretes a liquid of most disagreeable odour
the tail causes them to pass into a sort of proverb
They feed chiefly on roots , nuts , and other fruits
attack the nests of wasps , or wild bees
devour their larvæ themselves their honey with a perfect indifference to their stings , which can not pierce through their tough hide
their stings can not pierce through their tough hide
They prey at night
They live in the thickest parts of woods or coppices , where they rapidly dig deep holes , of their sharp and powerful claws
where they rapidly dig deep holes
These holes are divided into several chambers , the innermost of which is round
into several chambers , the innermost of which is round
These holes lined with hay or grass
All are kept very clean
every waste remnant of food and species of filth is deposited in holes dug on purpose for its reception
dug on purpose for its reception
The passages to the dwellings frequently turn at sharp angles , at which places the badgers make a stand when attacked
at sharp angles , at which places the badgers make a stand when attacked
the badgers make a stand
when attacked
Mr. St. John caused a badger hole to be dug out
he there found balls of grass
rolled up to the size of a man 's fist
evidently intended for food
That gentleman also says
that he has frequently found the bulb of the common blue hyacinth lying near the hole
lying near the hole
They devour besides all sorts of vegetables , small animals whether alive or dead , snails and worms
their peculiar dainty consists of eggs
A partridge nest affords them a delicious feast
particularly if they include the sitting hen
Badgers have a chest jaw
peculiarly formed
a chest jaw give them great strength
their forehead is so in consequence of a ridge which runs down the middle of it
a ridge runs down the middle of it
that they are by a blow in front which would kill an ox
a blow in front would kill an ox
while almost a touch at the back of the head will cause their destruction
Their thick skin lies loosely upon them
Their thick skin is much used making pistol cases
their fur is for painter 's brushes
They are to kill
few dogs have courage enough to attack them in their holes , where they live in pairs
where they live in pairs
When thus pursued
they constantly impede the progress of their enemies throwing the soil behind them so as to fill up the passages
while they escape to the surface
They are rare
They are to be found in various parts of the world
The Chinese eat them of their bad odour
When tamed they show great affection
an interesting proof which is given Captain Brown in his popular Natural History , which I transcribe
his popular Natural History I transcribe
" Two persons ( in France ) went on a journey
passing through a hollow way
a dog was with them
a dog started a badger
a badger he attacked
a dog pursued
till he took shelter in a burrow under a tree
With some pains he was hunted out
he killed
called Chapelletiere
they agreed to drag him thither
as the commune gave a reward for every one which was destroyed
every one was destroyed
which they proposed
selling the skin
Not having a rope they twisted some twigs
they by turns drew him along the road
They had not proceeded
far when they heard the cry of an animal in seeming distress
They stopped to listen
when another badger approached them slowly
They at first threw stones at it
notwithstanding which it drew near
it came up to the dead animal
it began to lick it
it continued its mournful cry
surprised at this
The men desisted offering any further injury to it "
The men again drew the dead one along as before
determined not to quit its companion
when the living badger lay down on it
taking it gently by one ear
that manner was drawn into the midst of the village
nor could dogs boys men induce it to quit its situation to their shame
be
it said
they had the inhumanity to kill the poor animal afterwards to burn it
declaring
it could not be no than a witch
